Cap. 1. TO continue the prohibition of the exportation of corn, grain, meal, flour, bread, biscuit, and starch; and also of the extraction of low wines and spirits from wheat and wheat flour, for a further time; and also to prohibit the exportation of malt for a limited time.

CAP. XXVIII.

An act for punching offences committed by hackney coachmen and chairmen> within certain diJlriSs and places therein mentioned \ and for renewing the registry of carts and carriages.

WHEREAS doubts have arisen whether offences committed bj hackney coachmen and chairmen, within certain places, which by reason of the great increase and buildings, are now become the suburbs of the cities of London and West minder, are cognizable under an act, made in the ninth year of the reign of her late majesty Queen Anne, in regard such places were not the atiual suburbs cf either of the said cities at the time of passing the said at1, and that fomt of them are not comprised within the weekly bills of mortality: for remedy whereof, may it please your Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King's most excellent majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons, in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same. That from and after the Preamble. twenty-fourth day or June, one thousand seven hundred and Act 9* Anne, seventy-one, all and every the new squares, buildings, and 1771 |thepa-* rccts> the several parishes of Saint Mary le Bone; Saint

CAP. XXXI.

An act for the encouragement of the white Herring fishery.

WHEREAS the carrying on and improvement of the British white herring ffberies are of great importance to these kingdoms, by increajing the trade and navigation thereof and being a nvr-fery for seamen, and otherwise a means of employing and providing for great numbers of indtt/irious poor, provided that reasonablt encouraic-ment be given to such persons as are willing to carry on the said fisheries: therefore, and for the better regulation of the said trade, and for preventing fraudi and impositions in the management thereof be it enacted by the King's most excellent majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons, in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, that as an encouragement to all persons whatfo-eyer, as well bodies politick and corporate as others, to engage in the said white herring flfheries, that, from and after the twen-ty-second day of October, one thousand seven hundred and seven-Bounty of jos. ty-one, a bounty of thirty Shillings per ton shall be paid annual-per ton on the ly, in manner as herein after provided for, to the owner or ow-veflels em- ners of all decked vessels from twenty to eighty tons burthen, which shall be fitted out and employed in the said filheries, in manner and under the regulations herein after mentioned, and that, for the space and term of seven years, from and after the said twenty-second day of Ofleber, one thousand seven hundred and seventy-one, and to the efrd of the then next ensuing session of parliament.

CAP. XXXIV.

An aR for enabling certain persons to inclose and embank part of the river Thames, adjoining to Durham Yard, Salisbury Street, Cecil Street, and Beaufort Buildings, in the county of Middlesex.

Preamble. XX7HEREAS the cowrfe of the river Thames form a large V V bend or angle round the Surrey Shore, between Westminster Bridge and the New Bridge at Black Friars, in the middle of which bend the faii river is much wider than at either of the /aid bridges, which tends to weaken the rapidity of the Jiream, and thereby contributes to an accumulation of mud ana filth on the Weftroinfter side, and to a very extenftye sand bank, on the other side; and whereat the navigation of the said river is greatly impeded by the fold sand bank, 'especially at low water, and the mud and filth so collected on she north /bore renders the access to the wharfs and grounds on that side very difficult, and in some parts of the tide impofftble, to the manifefi injury of the publick, as well as private detriment to the proprietors of the said wharfs and grounds: and whereas the said navigation might be greatly improved, and the said nuisances and inconveniences confi-ierably diminijbed by an embankment on the north part of the faii river, within the bay or hollow of the said bend, which, by advancing the unequal and irregular fronts of the said wharfs and grounds into an uniform line, would give a proper direction to the Jiream, and, by narrowing the unnecessary width of the bed of the said river in this part, would confederacy deepen the channel thereof; and whereas John Adam, Robert Adam, James Adam, and William Adam, and James Paine, Architects, Dorothy Monk widow, Clementina Pawfon widows and William Kitchiner coal merchant, having

CAP. XXXV.

An act for reducing into one act of parliament the several laws relating to the keeping and carriage of gunpowder, and for more effectually preventing mfchiefs by keeping or carrying gunpowder in too great quantities.

WHEREAS the several affs which regulate the keeping and Preamble.

carriage of gunpowder within England are defective* and reqstire amendment, and the reducing them into one law would facilitate their execution: and whereas there is, at present, no provifson for regulating of the keeping and carriage of gunpowder in Scotland: be it therefore enacted by the King's most excellent majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons, in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same. That no person or persons shall have or keep, at any one time, being a dealer or dealers in gun* powder, more than two hundred pounds of gunpowder, and not being such, more than fifty pounds of gunpowder, in any house, mill, magazine, storehouse, warehouse, (hop, celiar, yard, wharf, or other building or place, occupied by the same person or per-ions, (all buildings and places adjoining to each other, and ocr cupied together, being to be deemed one house or place within this act) or on any river or other water, except in carriages loading or unloacting, or passing on the land, or in ships, boats, or vessels loading or unloacting, or passing on any river or other water, or detained there by the tide or bad weather, within the following limits; that is to say, within the cities of London or Westminster, or within three miles of either of them; or within any city, borough, or market town of Great Britain, or within one mile of the same; or within two miles of any palace or house of reGdence of his present Majesty, his heirs or successors, or of her present majesty the Queen, or any Queen*confort or dowager; or within one mile of arty gunpowder magazine belonging to his Majesty, his heirs or (ucceflors; or wit bin half a mile of any parish church; or in any other part of Great Britain, (except in places where it shall be lawful to keep unlimited quantities of gunpowder by force of the provisions herein-after contained) on pain of forfeiting all the gunpowder in specie beyond the quantity hereby allowed to be kept, and the barrels in which such gunpowder (nail be, and also one shilling for every pound of gunpowder beyond such allowed quantity.

CAP. XXXVII.

An act to prohibit the exportation of live, and ether

fiefhprovisions, from Great Britain, a limited time.

XI. Provided always, That all suits, prosecutions, or informations, for offences committed against this act, shall be commenced and made within the space of fix calendar months after the faft is committed, and not otherwise; any thing herein contained to the contrary notwithstanding.

An act for improving and completing the navigation of the I rivers Thames and Isis from the city of London to the town of Cricklade, in the county of Wilts.

XV. Preamble. No pier, Sec. to be built eaft-ward of Black House Nock. No wharfs. Sec* to be erected on the lands belonging to Mr. Hamilton. Proviso. Tmftees appointed. An act to regulate the makings keeping y and carriage of gunpowder, within Great Britain and to repeal the laws hen-t of ore made for any of those purposes.

WHEREAS the manufacture of gunpowder within Grez Britain, though necessary to he encouraged in refptft of i-. value of gunpowder, as an article of defence and commerce, jet oe?h to be regulated by law, in order to prevent the great mischiefs may arije from explofons occafmed by the improper conjiruftiou &i nfe of the mills, engines, and buildings, employed in the making of gr*-powdery and for keeping and carrying gunpowder in too great titieSy or in an improper manner: and whereas the act pqffcd in ? lajf J'ejfton of parliament, intituledy An act for reducing into one» of parliament the several laws relating to the keeping and ar-riage of gunpowder, and for more effectually preventing mli chiefs, by keeping or carrying gunpowder in too great quarni-ties, contains no provision for regulating the making of gttnpewdr, and is in other respects defeftivey on which account it may be estez: -nient to repeal the said afty andy in the room thereof \ to have a err law for regulatingy as well the making as the keeping and carriage d gunpowder \ be it therefore enacted by the King's mod excelfet majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritts1 and temporal, and commons, in this present parliament atffcm-bled, and by the authority of the same. That no person or persons shall use, or cause to be used any mill or mills, or other engine or engines, for the making of gunpowder, or ir> any ma-ner manufacture gunpowder in any place or places within Grai Britain, except in mills and other places where the mranufaftare of gunpowder shall be actually carrying on at the time of the commencement of this act, or where it shall afterwards becom: lawful to carry on such manufacture, by obtaining a licence for that purpose, under the provisions herein-after contained, upen pain of forfeiting all gunpowder manufactured contrary to the afore said provision, and also two shillings for every pound of such gunpowder.

II. And be it further enacted by the authority aforesaid. That no person or persons whatsoever shall, for the making of gunpowder, employ, work, or use, any mill or engine, worked with a pestle or pestles, and commonly called a Pejlle Milly upon pain of forfeiting all gunpowder manufactured therein, and also two shillings for every pound of such gunpowder.

III. CAP. LXXII.

An act for rendering the payment of the creditors of insolvent debtors more equal and expeditious, and fer regulating the diligence of the law by arrefiment and poindings and for extending the privilege of bills to promissory notes, and for limiting actions upon bills and promissory notes, in that part of Great Britain called Scotland.

WH E R E A S by the laws now fubfifing in that part of Great Preamble, Britain called Scotland, the personal ejiates of such debtors as become insolvent are generally carried off by the diligences of arrefi-went and poindings executed by a few creditors, whoy from the near-nefs of their refideme toy and connexion with such debtors, get the ear lie ft notice of the insolvency, to the great prejudice of creditors more remote and unconnected, and to the disappointment of that equality which ought to take place in the distribution of the estates of insolvent debtors among their creditors: therefore, to remedy such injufiice and inequality in time coming, and to render the payment of the creditors of insolvent debtors more equal and expeditious, may it please your most excellent Majesty that it may be enacted; and be it enacted by the King's most excellent majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons, in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same.
